channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Japan Fire May Have Killed Dozens, With Arson Suspected
item.description: The fire consumed the fourth floor of the building in Osaka, which housed a medical office.
item.dc:creator: Makiko Inoue and Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Firefighters after the blaze in Osaka, Japan, on Friday.

item.title: Stolen at Birth, Chilean Adoptees Uncover Their Past
item.description: Hundreds of Chileans adopted abroad have learned that they were trafficked. Investigators believe thousands of children may have been taken from their parents during Chile’s dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tyler Graf, 38, was adopted from Chile, and learned this year that he was one of hundreds — possibly thousands — of Chilean adoptees taken from their parents during the country’s military dictatorship.

item.title: Britain’s Conservatives Lose ‘Safe’ Seat, Dealing a Blow to Boris Johnson
item.description: The governing party lost to the Liberal Democrats a district that it had represented for more than a century.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: In the North Shropshire by-election, Helen Morgan, center, of the Liberal Democrats, defeated the Conservative candidate.

item.title: 12 Remaining Members of a U.S. Group Kidnapped in Haiti Have Been Released
item.description: Seventeen members of the group, Christian Aid Ministries, had been kidnapped by a gang in October. Five had been released earlier.
item.dc:creator: Harold Isaac, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ruth Graham
item.media:description: The gate of the Christian Aid Ministries facility this month in Titanyen, north of Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

item.title: The Island Paradise Near the Front Line of Tensions Over Taiwan
item.description: New missile batteries planned for the Japanese island of Ishigaki reflect a drastic shift in Japan’s views on China.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley, Hisako Ueno and The New York Times
item.media:description: A new missile base on Ishigaki, Japan, is making residents worry for their safety in case of a conflict between China and Taiwan.

item.title: Super Typhoon Rai Hits the Philippines
item.description: Nearly 100,000 people in several regions were evacuated, and at least 17 people died.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Aaron Favila/Philippine Goast Guard, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescuers helping residents through floodwaters caused by Typhoon Rai in Cagayan de Oro, a city in the southern Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Cracks Down on Firms Said to Aid China’s Repression of Minorities
item.description: The Commerce and Treasury Departments put new restrictions on an array of companies and institutions that they said were misusing biotechnology.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The Great Hall of the People alongside Tiananmen Square in Beijing. The Biden administration said China was using advances in biotechnology to drive forward its military modernization.

item.title: Congress Passes Ban on Goods From China's Xinjiang Region
item.description: President Biden is expected to sign the bill, which drew a fierce corporate lobbying campaign against it.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bill would ban the imports of goods made “in whole or in part” in Xinjiang unless companies are able to prove that the products were not made with forced labor.

item.title: NATO Signals Support for Ukraine Amid Russia Threat
item.description: The military alliance stood by its promise to open a path to Ukrainian membership amid warnings from Western intelligence agencies that Moscow could soon begin a military incursion.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian Army’s 25th Airborne Brigade on patrol in Avdiivka, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Turkish Currency Hits a New Low, Again
item.description: The Central Bank has cut interest rates, even as inflation continues to soar, deepening President Erdogan’s disputed economic plan and setting off a new plunge in the lira.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: People buying subsidized bread at a kiosk in Istanbul. Inflation in Turkey continues to soar as the lira hits new lows.

item.title: Judges in France Order the Reopening of an Enduring Murder Mystery
item.description: The conviction of Omar Raddad in the killing of a socialite in the French Riviera three decades ago will be re-examined after his lawyers presented new DNA evidence they say exonerates him.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Omar Raddad, a Moroccan-born gardener who was convicted for the 1991 murder of his wealthy employer, leaving after a hearing in Paris, on Nov. 25.

item.title: In Italy’s Alps, Traditional Medicine Flourishes, as Does Covid
item.description: The province of Bolzano has the country’s highest level of coronavirus infection and lowest vaccination rate, as many people there prefer to rely on the pure air and herbal remedies.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Dobbiaco in Bolzano province, where people are famously independent and often bristle at decrees from Rome.

item.title: ‘Selling Kabul’ Holds Up a New Mirror After the Taliban Takeover
item.description: Sylvia Khoury’s play, which takes place over one night in Afghanistan in 2013, has only deepened after a pandemic postponement.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: “A play is a fixed thing, as history continues,” the playwright Sylvia Khoury said about her decision not to update her play after the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan in August.

item.title: Expanding the Scope of ‘Latin American Art’
item.description: Eight not-to-be-missed shows offer scores of creators and local art traditions from New York, Puerto Rico and the Caribbean, Mexico and South America.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.category: Institute for Studies on Latin American Art (Manhattan, NY)
item.media:credit: Préfète Duffaut and El Museo del Barrio
item.media:description: Préfète Duffaut, a Haitian artist featured in “Popular Painters and Other Visionaries” at El Museo del Barrio. “Harbor, Vue de Jacmel Avec le Pont de Noël” (“View of Jacmel With the Noël Bridge”), from 1968, captures the seaport of Jacmel, where he lived and worked.

item.title: Russia Lays Out Demands for a Sweeping New Security Deal With NATO
item.description: The proposal, coming as Russia masses troops on the border with Ukraine, was directed at the United States and Ukraine’s other Western allies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Russia has amassed troops near its border with Ukraine in a military buildup that has raised alarms of an impending invasion.

item.title: Omicron Threatens Red America
item.description: In many communities, most adults remain unvaccinated.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Shoppers at a mall in Houston.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Omicron in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Testing for Covid-19 in New York City.

item.title: The Giant Who Lives in the Melbourne Museum
item.description: The world’s most complete triceratops skeleton ever found will go on display next year, displacing a beloved, if quirky, exhibit of taxidermy.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell

item.title: Scientists Are Racing to Gauge the Threat of Omicron
item.description: The variant will spread quickly through the United States, experts say. What happens after that is less certain.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Covid testing in Times Square this month. The share of cases caused by Omicron nationally has already increased to 2.9 percent from 0.4 percent in just a week.

item.title: Oriol Bohigas, Groundbreaking Spanish Architect, Dies at 95
item.description: He was a mastermind of the overhaul of Barcelona in preparation for the 1992 Summer Olympics, which helped transform much of the city.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder

item.title: C.D.C. Recommends Pfizer or Moderna Vaccines Over J.&J
item.description: A committee of experts voted on a preference for the Moderna or Pfizer immunizations, citing the risk of blood clots linked to Johnson & Johnson’s product.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: An expert panel discussed a higher incidence of a rare disorder, especially among women, that occurred shortly after they got their first J.&.J. shot.

item.title: France Limits U.K. Travel as Omicron Spreads
item.description: Omicron fuels record cases in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Information screens showing the upcoming Eurostar trains to London at the Gare du Nord railway station in Paris.

item.title: In 50 Words, Tell Us Your Best Pandemic Story
item.description: We want to hear about your Covid memories.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A 3-D Printed Pod Inflames the Assisted Suicide Debate
item.description: The pod, known as Sarco, was conceived as a way for people to end their lives without involving a doctor. A plan to introduce it in Switzerland has raised alarm even among right-to-die advocates.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: ‘They Were Just Gone’: Two Baby Boys Survive Tornado in Kentucky
item.description: Without a basement, Clara Lutz of Barnsley, Ky., sheltered her infant grandsons in the bathtub for safety. A powerful tornado pulled the tub from her grip and sent the babies flying.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr, Yousur Al-Hlou and Noah Throop

item.title: On Broadway, Covid is trying to steal every show.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Miguel Cervantes as the title character in “Hamilton” in September. The popular musical was one of several shows to cancel performances because of Covid cases this season.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth cancels traditional pre-Christmas lunch as cases surge in England.
item.description: Palace officials said it was a precautionary measure to avoid putting royal family members at risk by bringing a large group together at Windsor Castle.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Britain’s Queen Elizabeth at Windsor Castle near London last December.

item.title: Hu Xijin, Chief of China's Global Times, Will Retire
item.description: Mr. Hu, editor of the Communist Party tabloid Global Times, set the tone for a new generation of Chinese pundits with his flair for verbal combat.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and John Liu
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hu Xijin in the Global Times newsroom in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: An Omicron Surge is Likely, Here's What to Expect
item.description: We look at the latest on Omicron.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line at a London vaccination site.

item.title: France Bans Nonessential Travel With U.K. Over Omicron Surge
item.description: The French prime minister said the restrictions were necessary after “the extremely rapid spread” of Omicron in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Charles de Gaulle Airport near Paris. Starting Saturday, travel to or from Britain will be allowed for only “urgent” reasons.

item.title: What Happens If You Test Positive for Covid While Traveling?
item.description: In the midst of the holiday season, the Omicron variant has many considering the prospects of getting stuck while traveling. Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy

item.title: Battling for Bolivia’s Lithium That's Vital to Electric Cars
item.description: Chinese and Russian industrial giants seek to tap mineral deposits vital to electric cars. A Texas entrepreneur has his own strategy: the long game.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss and Meridith Kohut

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Omicron breaks records in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: England’s chief medical officer, Chris Whitty.

item.title: Bouncy Castle in Tasmania Is Swept by Wind, Killing 5 Children
item.description: A gust of wind swept up the inflatable on the last day of school, and the students fell more than 30 feet. Several others were critically injured.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Helicopters and ambulances rushed to the scene Thursday after heavy winds lifted a bouncy castle high in the air in Devonport, Australia.

item.title: Santo Domingo Plane Crash Kills All 9 Aboard
item.description: A prominent Puerto Rican music producer known as Flow La Movie was reported to be among the dead.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Security personnel patrolling in the vicinity of Las Americas International Airport in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, on Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: Omicron vs. vaccines
item.description: And the coming Omicron wave.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Daily reported coronavirus cases in the United States, seven-day average.

item.title: Canadian Government Warns Residents to Avoid Nonessential Travel
item.description: In response to the spread of Omicron, Canada is also ramping up distribution of booster doses and rapid antigen tests.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The home opener of the Vancouver Canucks in October, when Covid-19 capacity restrictions were lifted.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Xi and Putin Show Solidarity
item.description: The leaders met amid pressure from the West.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Xi Jinping, the leader of China, in 2019 in Brazil. The two leaders are presenting a united front against Western pressure.

item.title: Why Britain Thinks Omicron Infected 200,000 People on Monday
item.description: Experts called it ‘a back-of-the-envelope calculation’ that showed how quickly the variant spreads, but also how little is known about it.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Manchester, England, on Sunday.

item.title: After Months, a ‘New’ Dutch Coalition With the Same Leader and Parties
item.description: Mark Rutte, who has weathered a scandal and criticism for overstaying his welcome, will be prime minister for a fourth term.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Erdbrink
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Rutte last month in the Hague, the Netherlands. He has been leading the Netherlands since 2010.

item.title: Britain Breaks Daily Record for New Virus Cases
item.description: Officials didn’t specify what share of the new cases might be Omicron, though they said a majority in London were from the variant.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Many Turks Can’t Afford Bread, and Bakers Can’t Afford to Make It
item.description: Squeezed by rising costs, price controls and plunging sales, bakers warn of ruin, while their impoverished former customers line up for government-supplied loaves.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although government kiosks have been operating for years in working-class neighborhoods of Istanbul, many more people are now buying the cheaper bread.

item.title: Germany is investigating vaccine opponents over a plot to kill a state governor.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers block the entrance to the Saxony Parliament building in Dresden, Germany, during a protest against pandemic measures.

item.title: Iran Agrees to Replace Cameras at Nuclear Site but Blocks Images
item.description: Iran’s failure to allow the U.N. nuclear agency to fully monitor its nuclear program is hindering talks in Vienna on restoring the 2015 nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: EU Delegation In Vienna, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Talks in Vienna aimed at restoring the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran are going badly.

item.title: On Cruise Ships, Omicron Puts Safety Protocols to the Test
item.description: Many lines are adjusting their masking, testing and vaccine rules, while criticism is mounting about the lack of transparency in reporting positive cases to passengers and crew members.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:credit: James D. DeCamp/Zuma Press Wire, via Newscom
item.media:description: The Norwegian Breakaway, docked in New Orleans in November. The Norwegian Cruise Line ship reported 17 coronavirus cases the first week of December.

item.title: France Refused to Repatriate a Sick Woman Who Joined the Islamic State. She Died.
item.description: A Frenchwoman died of health complications in a detention camp in Syria on Tuesday, her lawyer said. She had repeatedly asked to be repatriated to treat severe diabetes.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A woman walking through Roj, the camp where relatives of people suspected of belonging to the Islamic State are being detained in Syria’s northeastern Hasakah Province.

item.title: Malta Becomes First E.U. Country to Legalize Marijuana
item.description: The government said that the new law was aimed at ending the criminalization of people for smoking the drug and at reducing criminal trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Malta’s new rules allow people to carry up to seven grams of marijuana, grow up to four plants in their apartments and keep up to 50 grams of dried cannabis at home.

item.title: Biden’s China Dilemma: How to Enforce Trump’s Trade Deal
item.description: The Biden administration must decide whether to enforce a Trump-era trade deal that has not fulfilled its promise.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: In a call last month with President Xi Jinping of China, President Biden underscored the importance of China fulfilling the commitments.

item.title: The U.S. secretary of state cuts his Asia trip short after a journalist on his plane tests positive.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the U.S. Embassy in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Vaccine Opponents in Germany Investigated Over Plot to Kill State Governor
item.description: The authorities in Dresden raided the homes of a group of people who they said were targeting the leader of the state of Saxony. A number of weapons were seized.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers leading a suspect out of a building in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday.

item.title: 5 Republican Governors Seek Vaccine Exemptions for National Guard Troops
item.description: The move comes as the Pentagon released a new order this week saying that National Guard members who do not get vaccinated would receive a general order of reprimand, essentially ending their careers.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Wyoming National Guard at the U.S. Capitol in Washington in February.

item.title: Blinken Halts Asia Trip After Journalist Tests Positive for Covid
item.description: Citing the need for caution, the secretary of state expressed “deep regret” to Thailand’s deputy prime minister before returning to the United States earlier than planned.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arriving in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday.

item.title: India's Supreme Court Mandates Benefits for Sex Workers
item.description: Officials must enter them into databases for voting and benefits, the judges said, after they suffered from the effects of Covid-19 lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A sex worker in a red light area of Sangli in the western state of Maharashtra, India, in June.

item.title: Two Doses of China's Sinovac Inadequate Against Omicron, Hong Kong Study Suggests
item.description: Laboratory experiments suggest that the Chinese vaccine provides little protection against an Omicron infection.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and John Liu
item.media:description: Lining up to receive China’s Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine at a community inoculation center in Hong Kong last month.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Must Return to Prison, South Africa Judge Rules
item.description: The former president had been granted medical parole two months into a 15-month prison sentence on contempt charges linked to a corruption inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Jacob Zuma in court in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, in October. A judge ruled on Wednesday that the former president’s health had not “deteriorated permanently or reached an irreversible state.”

item.title: Russian Is Convicted in Murder of Chechen Man in a Berlin Park
item.description: A German court ruled that the Russian state had orchestrated the attack, which strained ties between Berlin and Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Christoph Soeder/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers at the site in Berlin where Zelimkhan Khangoshvili was killed in 2019.

item.title: 2021 in Photos
item.description: It’s time to look at the Pictures of the Year.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

item.title: North Korea Executes People for Watching K-Pop, Rights Group Says
item.description: At least seven people have been put to death in the past decade for watching or distributing K-pop videos, as the North cracks down on what its leader calls a “vicious cancer.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, has at times tried to appear more flexible toward outside culture​. In 2018, he invited South Korean musicians to a rare concert in Pyongyang.

item.title: Australia eases restrictions even as it expects more Omicron cases.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Travelers arrived at Hobart Airport in Hobart, Australia, on Wednesday, as the country reopened to all fully vaccinated travelers from mainland states and territories.

item.title: Putin and Xi Hold Video Summit
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China, meeting in a video summit, sought mutual support in their conflicts with the West but have not yet declared a formal alliance.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Xi Jinping, the leader of China, in 2019 in Brazil. The two leaders are presenting a united front against Western pressure.

item.title: The Nobel Peace Prize That Paved the Way for War in Ethiopia
item.description: This is the story behind how Ethiopia’s prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, won a Nobel Prize for making peace with his country’s longtime enemy — and then used the alliance to plan a war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia drew early acclaim for his promise to unify his country.
